item.title: Abbaye de la Cambre
item.body: This abbey was founded in 1201 by a noble woman of Brussels named Gisèle, and was entrusted to the nuns of the Cistercian order. The buildings which were badly damaged during the Wars of Religion were rebuilt in the 16th century, and enlarged in the 18th century. Only certain parts of the church still date from the 14th century and belong to that transitional period between Gothic splendour and the flamboyant (Gardens).

item.title: Abbaye du Rouge Cloître
item.body: Of the 14th century buildings, only the south wing, which has been turned into a restaurant and bar, a part of the farm, the barns and the stables remain. Temporary exhibitions display the work of numerous artists in the art centre (Forest of Soignes).

item.title: Ancienne Chapelle des Brigittines
item.body: Built in the 17th century, abandoned in the 18th century, it was used as a dispensary in 1792 and finally as a school. After being restored in 1850, it was used for different purposes before adopting its present cultural purpose The old Chapel now has an extension, a contemporary twin.

item.title: Atomium
item.body:
Unmistakable symbol of Brussels and Belgium and unique feat in the history of architecture: the Atomium is today the most popular attraction in the Capital of Europe.

Built for the 1958 World Exhibition, the Atomium is shaped on the model of an elementary iron crystal enlarged 165 billion times.

Beyond surreal walks through tubes and spheres, the Atomium houses a permanent exhibition about its history as well temporary exhibitions for a broad public (sciences, design, society).

The upper sphere offers unique and spectacular views across the city skyline.

At night, 2970 lights offer a fairy dimension to the 102m high building. The panoramic restaurant is daily open until 11pm.
 
 
Atomium: sphere named after François Englert
After having named the event sphere Ilya Prigogine as a tribute to the Belgian Nobel Prize Winner in Chemistry 36 years ago, the Atomium has now decided to honour the new Belgian Nobel Prize Winner in Physics and name the lowest sphere, the first above the entrance, after physician and university professor François Englert.

item.title: Basilica of Koekelberg ( Panorama )
item.body: This is the fifth largest church in the world and the largest Art Deco edifice ever built. It houses the Musée des Sœurs Noires (museum of the black sisters) (open Wednesday 2 p.m.- 4 p.m. and by appointment) and the Musée d'Art moderne religieux (museum of religious modern art) (open Thursdays, Fridays and Sundays 2 p.m.- 4 p.m. and by appointment).

item.title: Beguinage d'Anderlecht (Musée du)
item.body: The narrow path leading to the Beguine convent enhances still further the intimacy of this site, which once offered refuge to eight Beguine nuns. The convent was founded in 1252 by William, Doyen of the Chapter of Anderlecht. The inner garden, with its covered well, is flanked by two rows of 14th century maisonettes.

item.title: Bibliothèque Royale de Belgique - Albertine
item.body: National and scientific library. More than 5 million books, several special sections including sections on museums and history, the Literature Museum, prints reading room, etc. This building also houses the Nassau Chapel. The chapel of Saint Georges is all that remains of the Nassau mansion built in Brabant gothic style at the end of the 15th century by Anglebert II of Nassau.

item.title: Botanique (Le) Centre culturel
item.body: The building in neoclassical style was built in 1826. The former Botanical Garden was transformed into a cultural centre in 1984. Due to its architecture and layout, it is almost unique, with its splendid tropical greenhouse having been turned into a central corridor with a rich variety of plants.

item.title: BOZAR
item.body: Erected in 1928 by the architect and master of Art Nouveau, Victor Horta, it is a centre of cultural and artistic life. A full renovation of the interior restored the original appearance of the building, as originally designed by the master, Horta. Visits are organised ("From Horta to Horta") to allow people to rediscover parts of the building previously off limits to the general public

item.title: Bruxella 1238 - Site Archéologique
item.body: Relics of the monastery and church of the Franciscan brothers, it encompasses archaeological objects and remains of the burial place of Duke Jean I. These are the foundations of the chancel of the church of the Franciscans, brothers of the minor orders or Recollects with, among other things, several burial vaults, including one which is probably that of Duke Jean I.

item.title: Centre Belge de la Bande Dessinée - CBBD - Stripmuseum
item.body:
The marriage of the 9th Art and Art Nouveau

Located in the heart of Brussels, in a majestic Art Nouveau building, created by Victor Horta in 1906, the Belgian Comic Strip Center opened its doors to the public on October 6th 1989. In no time this impressive museum became one of the main attractions of Brussels. Every year more than 200.000 visitors come here to explore 4.200 m² of permanent and temporary exhibitions.
 

Permanent exhibitions

The Invention of Comic Strip
How did the comic strip begin, and how is it defined? This exhibition takes you on a journey in enormous strides through the history of the world and its civilisations.
 
The Art of Comic Strip
This exposition proposes to explore the comic strip in all its forms, from the creative process to the range of genres that constitute the European comic strip today.
 
Horta and the Waucquez Warehouse
This exhibition tells the story of a shop the like of which is no longer seen. Now over 100 years old, this is the only semi-industrial building designed by Victor Horta still in existence today. And what an existence it has had!
 
The Museum of Imagination (1929-1959)
This exhibition shows the greatest moments in the history of the European comic strip, popularised by the Belgian pioneers. From Hergé to Roba, it explores the careers and works of the authors who have made Belgium the Kingdom of the Comic Strip.

item.title: Collégiale St Pierre et Guidon
item.body: This is one of the most remarkable edifices in Brabant. Although the date of its foundation is not known, it goes back to at least the 11th century. The present church, constructed from the 14th to the 16th century, is a magnificent Gothic edifice. Its Romanesque crypt from the 11th century is one of the oldest and most interesting monuments of this style in the country. The crypt contains a very old tombstone, with a branch bearing a few leaves as its only design. Traditionally believed to be the tomb of Saint Guido. Four columns in this crypt may have come from a Roman villa. Stained-glass windows in the chancel from the 15th and 16th centuries. The spire of the tower is a neo-Gothic addition from 1898.

item.title: Commission Européenne - Le Berlaymont
item.body: The first European building to be constructed in Brussels at the end of the 1960s, the Berlaymont is back on its feet after a long and arduous face lift. The new structure, now fully modular, is home to a part of the army of civil servants of the European Commission.

item.title: Conservatoire Royal de Musique
item.body: The French neo-Renaissance-style buildings stand on Rue de la Régence on the spot where it cuts in two the old site of the Thurn and Taxis building.The school of music founded in 1827 became the conservatory five years later.

item.title: Coudenberg - Former Palace of Brussels
item.body:
An underground tour discovering the remains of the palace of Charles V

From the middle ages, a castle overlooked Brussels from Coudenberg hill. From the 12th century, the successive monarchs and their representatives transformed a small fortified castle into a sumptuous residential palace, one of the most beautiful palace of Europe and one of Charles V's main residences.

This prestigious building is severely damaged by fire in 1731. Some forty years later, the ruins of the palace are pulled down and the ground flattened out for the construction of the new royal district. The remains of this palace make up the Coudenberg archaeological site.
During your visit, you will discover the Rue Isabelle and the old structures of the main buildings of the former palace of Brussels, which are now the foundations for today's royal district and the Hoogstraeten House where the most interesting discoveries made during the various archaeological excavations conducted on the Coudenberg are displayed.
item.address: Place des Palais 7 (Entrée via le musée BELvue)/Paleizenplein 7 (Ingang via het BELvue museum)

item.title: Crypte de la Place des Martyrs - Cimetière des Combattants 1830
item.body: This beautiful neo-classical square, erected on the site of a former "stenter", a meadow for drying cloth, was developed by the architect Claude Fisco in 1774 with the aim of inaugurating a middle-class residential structure in the heart of the city. In the middle of it stands a memorial monument in honour of patriots fallen in the battles fought to achieve independence in 1830.

item.title: De Beursschouwburg
item.body: (Electro / Break / Jazz) - The Beurs is first and foremost an amazing Flemish cultural venue that, with its contemporary design, has made its mark. So its long bar leaves room for a rather artistic and intellectual crowd. Music is ubiquitous, including DJ sets and live music for the initiated. In the evenings, they lounge around big communal tables in a general but very friendly and sociable hubbub, before moving to the various upstairs rooms and dancing the night away. Open Thursday to Saturday from 8 p.m.

item.title: Eglise des Minimes (St Jean et Etienne)
item.body: Remarkable due to its style and harmonious proportions, it marks the transition between the 17th century Flemish Baroque and the neo-classicism which became popular in the 18th century.

item.title: Eglise Notre Dame aux Riches Claires
item.body: This 17th century church built in the Flemish Renaissance style is the work of Luc Fayd'herbe and is typical of the Brabant Baroque style. It was enlarged in 1831. It has reopened after restauration work following a fire wich destroyed it in June 1989.

item.title: Eglise Notre Dame de la Chapelle
item.body: Remarkable due to its Romanesque and Romanesque-Gothic architecture, it is one of the most interesting in Belgium. One of its chapels is devoted to the memory of Pieter Bruegel the Elder and his wife, Marie Coucke. In the Chapel of the Holy Sacrament, a commemorative plaque serves as a reminder that François Anneessens, the leader of the guilds who was executed for having defended communal liberties, is buried there.

item.title: Eglise Notre Dame de Laeken
item.body: Constructed in the 19th century and dedicated to Louise-Marie, first Queen of the Belgians, it contains the Royal Crypt. The choir of the original 13th century church is in early Gothic style and is in the cemetery where numerous well-known personalities are buried. They include, the playwright Michel de Ghelderode, the architects Poelaert, Balat and Suys as well as the violinist Charles de Bériot and his wife, the famous opera singer, known as "La Malibran". Among the works of art decorating the tombs and chapels is the famous "Thinker" of Rodin. (renovation works)

item.title: Eglise Notre Dame du Finistère
item.body: This 18th century church is built on the site of a chapel founded in the 15th century and named "de Venstersterre". A Gothic virgin, Notre-Dame du Bon Succès, is worshipped here.

item.title: Eglise Notre Dame du Sablon
item.body: This precious example of the flamboyant Gothic style so admired in Brabant owes its splendour to the city's Guild of Crossbowmen that built it in the 15th century. It stands on the site of the 14th century chapel, built to venerate the small miraculous statue recovered by Beatrice Soetkens and brought back from Antwerp to Brussels in 1348. Several members of the royal court are buried in Sablon. In the chapel of Saint Ursula, to the west of the chancel, lie at rest Thurn and Taxis, postmasters of the Habsburg empire.

item.title: Eglise Protestante de Bruxelles
item.body: Prince Charles de Lorraine laid the first stone on 1 May 1760. King Leopold 1, who was a Protestant, attended church here.

item.title: Eglise Royale Sainte Marie
item.body: This church, in the eclectic style, combines neo-Byzantine elements with neo-Romanesque and neo-Gothic references. In 1849, the architect Louis Van Overstraeten died aged 30. It was Gustave Hansotte who completed the project in 1853. It was the first time that a cupola was made in gilded bronze with a metal framework. Its powerful octagonal silhouette and the dome dominate the view from the rue Royale. Prettily lit in the evenings.

item.title: Eglise Saint Nicolas
item.body: Dedicated to the patron saint of merchants, its origins go back to the birth of the city. Completely rebuilt and restored, this church has a rich collection works of art by Jean Van Orley, Smeyers, Stallaert, canvases from the Carrache school and a painting attributed to Rubens.

item.title: Eglise Sainte Catherine
item.body: Built on the site of the ancient 17th century church, it is the inspiration of the architects Poelaert and Janssens. Originality lies in its mixture of different styles, although it does not totally succeed in marrying them. Its collection of paintings is, however, worth seeing.

item.title: Eglise Sainte Marie Madeleine
item.body: A small gothic church with a great baroque gate, it was once part of a convent founded in the 13th century which was handed over to the Protestants in 1579. The Chapel was destroyed in the bombardment of 1695, but was rebuilt shortly thereafter thanks to a donation from the bakers' guild. It was restored between 1957 and 1958 to its 15th century appearance.

item.title: Eglise Saint-Jacques-sur-Coudenberg
item.body: The facade is an exact replica of a Roman peristyle. During the French revolution it was converted into a Temple of Reason and then a Temple of the Law, before returning to Catholic worship in 1802.

item.title: Galeries Royales Saint-Hubert
item.body: Initiated by the architect Jean-Pierre Cluysenaer, the spectacular Galeries Royales project took shape in the 1830s. The works, begun in 1846, were almost completed in time for the official opening on 20 June 1847. The gallery included shops, auditoriums, cafés, restaurants and apartments. The place to be seen for the fashionable, right away, the Royal Galleries of Saint Hubert drew a wide audience, attracted by its luxury brands, elegant cafés and cultural spaces. These included the Théâtre du Vaudeville, the Cinéma des Galeries and the Taverne du Passage, called the Café des Arts until 1892 and the meeting place for painters and writers of the time. The colony of French refugees, like Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas, Edgar Quinet and others, would also gather there. The Surrealist painters and artists from the Cobra group were regulars at the venue. A commemorative plaque recalls the first showing of the Lumière brothers’ motion picture camera on 1 March 1896, in the former dispatch room of the La Chronique daily newspaper (above Pâtisserie Meert, Galerie du Roi). Nowadays, the Galerie du Roi is home to the Museum of Letters and Manuscripts and honours the greatest men and women of art, history, music, the humanities and science.

item.title: Halles de Schaerbeek (Les)
item.body: One of the last examples of industrial architecture of the 19th century. This covered market is unique in Brussels for its interior design, and also for its varied programme of important and original cultural events.

item.title: Halles Saint-Géry
item.body: The covered market halls stand on the site of the church of Saint-Géry, which was built in the 16th century in the middle of the Grande Ile. An old tradition has it that the chapel which preceded that church was the oratory of Charles of France, who is said to have been the founder of Brussels. Historic research raises increasing doubts on this subject. But the place is important: around the Ile (historic centre) there used to be four watermills, the sources of power of medieval industry. We are truly at the historic heart of Brussels here. After the church was demolished during the French Revolution, an obelisk fountain which came from Grimbergen abbey was erected in the middle of the square. The Saint-Géry market was built in 1881 around this obelisk by the architect Dubois. It now houses two associations entrusted with the heritage and environment of Brussels, and many exhibitions are held there.

item.title: Hôtel Hannon - Espace Contretype
item.body: In 1902 the engineer Edouard Hannon (1853 - 1931) called upon his friend, the architect Jules Brunfaut (1852 - 1942) to build this mansion, a masterpiece in the Art Nouveau style. At the present time the building is occupied by the Contretype Photographic organisation which is devoted to the promotion of creative photography by organising, in particular, exhibitions.

item.title: Hôtel Wielemans - Art Media
item.body: This superb house was built in 1925 at the request of Léon Wielemans, the owner of the Wielemans-Ceuppens brewery for his wife. The plans were drawn up by Adrien Blomme. Mrs Wielemans was an admirer of Spain: she therefore asked the architect to reproduce the Alhambra style of Granada, the city where she spent her holidays. No less than 4,803 tiles: azulejos, guardillas, etc were brought from Andalusia. Exhibitions on a temporary basis.

item.title: Le Brass
item.body: The first centre dedicated to the new technologies and the digital arts has opened in the old brewing rooms of a brewery.

item.title: Maison A Niguet
item.body: Designed by the architect Paul Hankar in 1896, this building is well worth a detour. A large, tree-covered, undulating window reveals a glimpse of an immaculate interior with exotic accents. Restored in 2002 according to original plans, the shop now houses a talented florist.

item.title: Maison Cauchie
item.body: The architect Cauchie built this house for himself in 1905. His headed note-paper stated "company specialising in fully furnished, decorated and embellished interiors". The house has a spectacular Art Nouveau façade.

item.title: Maison Erasme
item.body: The history of the museum at the Erasmus House is closely linked to that of the Chapter of Anderlecht (16th century). Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam stayed at this very house in 1521. The house was converted into a museum in 1932. The collections (furniture, works of art, engravings, books and archives) today form a unique collection illustrating assorted stages in European history: the Renaissance, the reign of Charles Quint, the Humanist movement, the flowering of printing, and burgeoning religious conflict. The philosophical garden is a garden of pleasures and knowledge. A reading room containing one of the world's largest collections of 16th century volumes can be visited by arrangement.

item.title: Maison (Hôtel) Solvay
item.body: This luxurious residence was built by V. Horta in 1894 for the Solvay family. The architect was given a free hand and designed the interior and furnishings down to the last detail. This is an absolute must for visitors.

item.title: Maison Otlet
item.body: Otlet had this house built by the architect O. Van Rysselberghe. The architect broke with the academic traditions which dominated architecture, whilst at the same time conserving several traces of the Italian renaissance. It was completed in 1894. The interior design was entrusted to H. van de Velde.

item.title: Maison P. Hankar
item.body: Hankar had it built in 1893. The façade of this first important work of Paul Hankar presents, by its innovative design, a break with historical architecture.

item.title: MIM - Musée des Instruments de Musique
item.body: This excellent museum occupies the old Art Nouveau buildings of the Old England stores (3000m2 of exhibition space) and is one of the biggest collection of instruments in the world. The four exhibition levels display nearly 1200 instruments (from the 7000 items of the entire collection), antique or contemporary, in a stage set blending the acoustic and visual aspects and integrating technological tools such as interactive terminals and sound spaces. People with visual disability can also enjoy a tailor-made visit, thanks to a tactile and customised approach offered in an interactive place, the Jardin d'Orphée. People with hearing difficulties will be able to do the same by feeling the vibrations of the instruments and trying them out. The museum also has training, activity and research spaces... as well as a library - (T (0)2 545 01 70) specialising in musical instruments.

item.title: Musée de la Porte de Hal
item.body: Porte de Hal, the last vestige of the second fortified city wall of Brussels, is one of the most emblematic historic buildings of our capital. Behind the fully renovated white façade of the freshly restored Porte de Hal, visitors can learn about the history of the building and its occupancy through the centuries, in the form of a brand new permanent presentation. It also shows and explains the history of the city, its defence, its corporations and its folklore, so many facets that prove to be closely linked to each other. Among the exhibits, visitors can admire, in particular, several famous masterpieces including guild neck-chains, the full-dress ceremonial armour of Archduke Albert, his stuffed horse and that of his wife the Infanta Isabelle, the so-called "Charles V" cradle or the painting attributed to Anthonis Sallaert, depicting the Infanta Isabelle taking part in the festival of crossbowmen in Sablon. As for the third floor and the top floor of Porte de Hal, they are reserved for temporary exhibitions and events.

item.title: Musée de la Ville de Bruxelles (Maison du Roi)
item.body: This superb historic building was rebuilt in the 19th century as a copy of the 16th century original, the site having been occupied from the 12th century by a bread hall. The museum is devoted to all aspects of the city's history. On the ground floor, don't miss the city's plastic and decorative arts (painting, sculpture, polyptych, tapestry, earthenware and silverware). The first floor traces the city's urban development and growth. The second floor spotlights the history of political, economic, cultural and social life in the capital. Paintings, artefacts, engravings, scale-models, etc. The museum's folklore section is home to the extravagant wardrobe of Brussels's most mischievous little inhabitant: Manneken-Pis. One of the richest collections of costumes imaginable: some 760 costumes, from the 18th century to the present day. The whole collection has just been freshly renovated and comes to life in a new and appealing interactive scenography.

item.title: Far East Museum - Japanese Tower - Chinese Pavilion
item.body: The Chinese pavilion was built on the edge of the Royal Estate at Laeken on the orders of King Leopold II between 1901 and 1910. The wooden panelling on the outside of the Chinese Pavilion and its entry pavilion were sculpted in Shanghai. The pavilion houses a major collection of Chinese ceramics manufactured for export to Europe. Following the Paris Universal Exhibition in 1900, King Leopold II decided to commence building-work on the Japanese Tower. Work was entrusted to the Parisian architect, Alexandre Marcel, known for his oriental-style buildings. It was he who purchased the entry pavilion to the Japanese Pagoda, built by a Japanese carpenter, at the Paris Universal Exhibition, and had it decorated by specialists from Yokohama. Next to the Chinese pavilion, a new museum is home to exhibitions on various aspects of Japanese art.

item.title: Musée du Cinquantenaire
Musée du Réverbère
item.body: Best visited at sunset, this open air museum, a strange combination of art and social history, exhibits around twenty public street lamps that show the evolution of street lighting in Brussels. Enamel plaques shed even more light on the background of each type of street lamp.
item.address: Entre 75 -87 Rue Emile Delva/Tussen 75 -87 Emile Delvastraat

item.title: Musée Horta
item.body: The Horta Museum is established in the private house and studio of the famous architect, Victor Horta (1861 - 1947). Built between 1898 and 1901, the two buildings are characteristic of Art Nouveau at its peak. The house has kept intact most of its interior decors: mosaics, stained-glass windows, furniture, paintings and murals form a collection whose every detail evokes harmony and sophistication. The museum is also a centre for research into Victor Horta and Art Nouveau. The architect's personal archives, a collection of blueprints for his buildings and a library are open to the public by arrangement.

item.title: Palais de Charles de Lorraine - Musée du 18e siècel
item.body: This museum is the result of collaboration between the Royal Museums of Art and History, the Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium and the Royal Library, and charts 18th century intellectual life. The Palace comprises five salons, each presenting a particular aspect: the life of Charles of Lorraine, scientific instruments, cartography, music, and the art of table-setting. (closed for renovation works)

item.title: Palais Stoclet
item.body: This luxurious house was built in 1911 by the Viennese architect Joseph Hoffmann. The outside of the building is entirely covered with white marble framed by gilded mouldings and is the only one of its kind in Brussels (cannot be visited).

item.title: Panorama Arcades du Cinquantenaire
item.body: Built between 1904 and 1905 by the architect Charles Girault, this triple arcade commemorates the fiftieth anniversary of Belgian independence. It is crowned by a quadriga in bronze, the work of Thomas Vinçotte and Jules Lagae. For the viewing platform: access via the royal Museum of the Army and Military History.

item.title: Parlement de la Région de Bruxelles-Capitale
item.body: Visits with appropriate introduction, questions and dialogues with members of the regional parliament.

item.title: Parlement Européen
item.body: The European Parliament is the only supranational institution whose members are democratically elected by direct universal suffrage. It represents the people of the Member States. The European Parliament is elected every five years, and is involved in drafting numerous laws (directives, regulations etc.) that affect the daily life of every citizen.

item.title: Parlement Fédéral - Palais de la Nation
item.body: This was built in 1783, based on the plans designed by the French architect Barnabé Guimard, for the Sovereign Council of Brabant. Originally known as the Palais des Etats-Généraux in 1817, it became the Palace of the Nation after 1830. To observe a plenary session from the public galleries, please check that the Chamber or the Senate is sitting on a given date (by consulting the Official Gazette or telephoning)

item.title: Tintin statue in Ukkel & on the Grand Sablon
item.body:
Uccle Cultural Centre is home to a life-size statue of Tintin and Snowy, created by Belgian sculptor Nat Neujean who designed the work at the request of Raymond Leblanc, the founder of Éditions du Lombard, who commissioned the sculpture to celebrate 30 years of Tintin magazine.

On 21 October 2011, Brussels revealed a new symbol in honour of Hergé and his creation. Now, Le Sablon/De Zavel has a Tintin and Snowy statue which Tintinologists and other fans can come and admire any time of year.

item.title: Villa Empain - Boghossian Foundation
item.body: Opening of Villa Empain to the public according to several themes of organised activities and events (exhibitions, concerts, conferences, etc.) from 2010. La Fondation Boghossian has its international office in Villa Empain, on which restoration work began in 2008. With the Stoclet building, constructed by the Austrian architect Josef Hoffmann in 1911, Villa Empain is undoubtedly one of the finest masterpieces of Art Deco architecture in Brussels. In 1930, Baron Louis Empain, then aged 21 years, had this 2,500-metre-square mansion built on the prestigious Avenue des Nations, which was later renamed Avenue Franklin Roosevelt. He entrusted the building of this fine house to the Swiss architect Michel Polak, assisted by his colleague Alfred Hoch. The plan designed for Baron Empain on a 55-acre plot included a monumental villa with four façades in polished granite, a garden surrounding a swimming pool ornamented with a pergola, and a caretaker's lodge. The modern and luxurious nature of this structure soon aroused enthusiasm and curiosity. It is true that the variety and quality of the materials used (marble, polished granite, bronze, wrought iron, stained-glass windows and precious woods), the sophistication of the details and the coherence of the whole thing with simple but imposing lines immediately contributed to its patrimonial value.

item.title: Wiels - Centre d'Art Contemporain
item.body: WIELS, the Contemporary Art Centre in Brussels, is an international laboratory for the creation and the diffusion of contemporary art. The program of WIELS focusses on seven to nine large-scale exhibitions a year, and is strengthened by a series of parallel activities (conferences, debates, exchanges, workshops, community programs and interdisciplinary confrontations...) that makes it an innovating and experimental art centre. In the heart of Europe, WIELS constitutes a unique contemporary art institution with regards to its international dimension, its specific objectives as well as the remarkable architecture of its building.

item.title: The Bois de la Cambre
item.body: Covering an area of 124 hectares, this is part of the old Forest of Soignes. It was annexed to the city in 1842, and its layout conceived by the landscape architect Keilig. On Saturdays and Sundays, some routes are closed to cars, thus leaving the way free for cyclists, joggers, roller-skating enthusiasts, etc. Weekend Family Robinsons can, once again, take the ferry to reach the island and have something to eat there.

item.title: Laeken Cemetery
item.body: Ornamented with monuments each more prestigious than the next, it is gradually becoming the "Belgian Père-Lachaise", drawing inspiration from the Parisian example of 1804. The final resting place of the nobility and the middle classes, over the 19th and 20th centuries, it amassed the burial places of the most eminent figures of the political, financial, artistic (the singer La Malibran, the architects J. Poelaert and A. Balat), social and intellectual worlds. A real summary of artistic trends from neoclassicism to expressionism, via Romanticism and every new wave, this open-air funeral museum preserves the works of some of the greatest architects and artists. (Renovation works)

item.title: Ixelles' ponds
item.body: In the past, strings of ponds used to run along the valley of Maelbeek, around Brussels. In Ixelles remain two of those ponds. Places for picturesque walks lined with majestic trees, Art Nouveau houses and the Flagey cultural centre. Nearby are the gardens of Abbaye de la Cambre (la Cambre Abbey) where a peaceful atmosphere reigns.
item.address: Avenue du Général de Gaulle/Generaal de Gaullelaan

item.title: Mellaerts ponds
item.body: A magnificent screen of greenery on the edge of the city, in the middle of Woluwe Park. Thanks to the keen interest of Leopold II, this beautiful site has been landscaped and conserved (mini-golf, boating, fishing). As soon as winter sets in again, they become the inevitable place for ice-skaters to meet up.

item.title: Forest of Soignes
item.body: The Forest of Soignes plays a role of paramount importance in the life of the people of Brussels.A marvellous beech forest which in 1822 still covered 12,000 hectares. Today, alas, only a third of it remains. In the Forest you will find: The Geographical Arboretum of Tervuren How to get there: N4, E411 (Namur) exit 2 (Jezus-Eik) / Kapucienendreef / Arboretumwandeling / Woudmeesterdreef Groenendael Arboretum How to get there: from the pont de Groenendael, take the direction of Duboislaan; then on the right Lange Staartdreef (Arboretumweg on the right). The Rouge Cloître site is one of the most interesting in the forest: 6 ha of dense trees, ponds, a restaurant, an art centre, etc... For all information on activities available in Forêt de Soignes, see the website.

item.title: Les jardins du fleuriste
item.body: Just a short walk from the Domaine Royal de Laeken (Royal Estate of Laeken), these gardens are the result of Leopold II's wishes. This majestic leafy-green area extended the Stuyvenberg Estate. In 1999, a public park was created there. The different gardens which now make up the park reinterpret the historic nature of the site and give it a refined modernity, whilst meeting the strictest environmental standards. As the highpoint of the visit, the balconies emphasise the sweeping view that stretches from Notre-Dame de Laeken to the Palais de Justice (law courts).

item.title: The Park of Brussels
item.body: In the 1770s, the whole district of the Court (now Place Royale and the Park) was transformed. The architect Guimard drew the plan for the new park. He was assisted by the gardener Zinner, to whom Guimard's role has wrongly been attributed. It was in this park that the first battles took place between the Belgian patriots and the Dutch troops in 1830.

item.title: The Cinquantenaire Park
item.body: This park was created in 1880 to host the exhibition organised to celebrate Belgian's fifty years of independence. Eight statues of women, symbolising the provinces surround it, the two Flanders being represented by a single statue. This regal expanse of greenery surrounds the Arcade, the Royal Museums of Art and History, the Royal Museum of the Army and Military History and Autoworld, the Horta Pavilion.

item.title: Josaphat Park
item.body: A spot praised by writers and artists, a refuge for botanists and ornithologists, the park also has a collection of sculptures, as well as areas set aside for sporting activities and young people. In July and August, free concerts are organised on the bandstand (cycling and roller skating are prohibited).

item.title: Léopold Park
item.body: A small island of tranquillity on the edge of the big sites of the European district. A landscaped, undulating park, which houses the Museum of the Institute of Natural Sciences and other scientific institutes, such as the magnificent Solvay Library, the work of Henry van de Velde. Today the library hosts cultural events.

item.title: Petit Sablon
item.body: Inaugurated in 1890, the square is surrounded by a superb wrought-iron balustrade, decorated with 48 bronze statuettes which represent the ancient crafts once practised in Brussels. There are ten statues decorating the rear of the park, intended to illustrate the 16th century in Belgium through the country's celebrated scholars and humanists, such as Mercator, Abraham Ortelius, Louis Van Bodeghem, Rombaud Dodonée, amongst others. In the centre, the statues of the Counts of Egmont and Hornes symbolise the fight against Spanish tyranny in the 16th century. The pedestal is decorated with the coats of arms of the two lords.

item.title: Place du Grand Sablon
item.body: This veritable mecca of antique dealers is surrounded by former mansion houses and is always bustling. At weekends the atmosphere is particularly lively with its thriving Book and Antiques market. In the centre of the square there is the fountain of Minerva, built in 1751, as a symbol of the gratitude of Lord Bruce, the Count of Aylesbury and English peer, for the hospitality he received in Brussels.

item.title: Eglise du Béguinage (St Jean Baptiste)
item.body: Attributed to the architect L. Fayd'Herbe, his church is a remarkable illustration of the Italian-influenced Flemish Baroque style of the 17th century. Its facade is considered to be one of the most beautiful in Belgium.

item.title: La Bourse de Bruxelles
item.body: Built in 1873, on the former site of the convent des Recollets, it was designed by the architect Léon Suys. Rodin collaborated on the exterior decoration of the building as an employee of Carrier-Belleuse. While the former became a famous sculptor, the latter is a name familiar only to specialists now. Of neoclassical inspiration, its simplicity is broken by very ornate decorations that have been described by some people as baroque excesses.

item.title: Maison privee
item.body: One of the most surprising Art Nouveau façades in Brussels is the work of Léon Delune, dating from 1904.

item.title: Maison Autrique
item.body: The first building created by Horta, the Autrique house has been entirely renovated and brought to life thanks to the imagination of the scriptwriters and cartoonists Schuiten and Peeters.

item.title: Hôtel Max Hallet
item.body: House dating from 1904, built according to the plans of V. Horta and offering a symphony of colours, whorls and lights to lift the heart and please the eyes. The lawyer Max Hallet had it built to receive his friends and clients in a magnificent setting. Victor Horta built it in the image of its occupant, laying out rooms for living and areas for receiving visitors.

item.title: Botanique park
item.body:
The Parc du Botanique is an oasis, a little noisy, in the heart of the town. Located close by the Rue Neuve, you can visit its rose garden, the rare trees and the Iris in flower from April till June.

Open till 17h30 in the winter and till 21h00 in the summer.

item.title: Elisabeth park
item.body:
The 21 ha of the park are located on the plateau of Koekelberg; they present a long promenade network, comparable to the one of the Cinquantenaire, punctuated with lawns and trees clumps alternated with groves and flower-beds. The park also contains some fittings for leisure purposes, resting area, playground...

The drawing of the park evokes the Royal monogram of Léopold II, under whose reign it was designed, simultaneously with the perspective of the Basilique du Sacré-Coeur and the very long one of the Boulevard Leopold II.

item.title: Roi Baudouin Park
item.body:
The Parc Roi Baudouin is consists of the Bois du Laerbeek, Poelbos, Parc du Sacré-Coeur and Bois de Dieleghem. The discovery of varied biotopes or natural or half-natural sites is among the good reasons to discover this green paradise in the North-West of Brussels. The rural aspect has been underlined with kitchen gardens and the Ferme des Enfants.

It is made up of several parts or "phases" corresponding to specific kinds of arrangements: phase I and II: classical parks (alternation of lawns, ponds, plants clumps, woods and arrangements for kids), phase III: more rural zone with prairies, small woods, hedges and wet areas.

item.title: Tintin Comic strip wall (Rue de l'Etuve)
item.body: The most famous and the most Belgian of the comic strip heroes finally has his place in the historic heart of Brussels. Hergé drew this simple block in one of his famous albums, ‘The Calculus Affair’, published in 1956.

item.title: "Le Passage" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: With his passion for architecture, this winner of the major Angoulème prize, François Schuiten invites you once again to enter a parallel universe incorporating one of his “Cités Obscures” (Dark cities) Another of Schuiten’s frescos can be found in the Porte de Hal tram station.

item.title: "The Scorpion" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: This realist-style fresco (and one of the only ones on the trail) created by Marini and Desberg illustrates the new school of Belgian comic strip. Desberg is the scriptwriter of several comic strips that you’ll discover on this trail, including “Billy the cat” and “La Vache”.

item.title: statue of Gaston
item.body: Eternal blunderer created by the talented Franquin

item.title: "Spike & Suzy" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Spike and Suzy were created by the late lamented Willy Vandersteen, the cartoonist who drew Bessy, Robert and Bertrand, etc…, taken up since then by the Vandersteen studios. Against a red background, as on the cover of one of their 250 albums, Spike and Suzy cheerfully brighten up the crossroads, helped by the formidable strength of our national icon, Manneken-Pis, who is compelled on this occasion to adjust his otherwise eternal posture.

item.title: "Billy the Cat" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: This cat was created by Stéphane Colman in 1979 for publication in the Spirou magazine. Fortunately, he had not listened to the famous Jijé a few years previously when he showed him his illustration plates and was advised to become a bus driver instead.

item.title: "Cubitus" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: A very white, very tubby, but not always cute hero, the dog Cubitus drawn by Dupa has taken the place of Manneken-Pis (yep, him again ! He’s small but much-talked about here) and now looks down on the district of the Marché aux Poissons (Fishmarket). A philosopher when the fancy took him, this funny little animal appeared in 1968 in the Tintin newspaper where he began to give his master Sémaphore a rough time.

item.title: "Blake & Mortimer" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: An image that’s become almost mythical in the world of comic strip in Belgium and beyond its borders, the Yellow Mark of Edgar P. Jacobs spreads panic in the streets of London... or could it be Brussels?

item.title: The Angel (Yslaire) Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Don’t be surprised about the contrast between the bottom and top of this wall; they were indeed drawn by the same cartoonist… At the bottom, the link with the city is direct. Symbolical and existential phrases inscribed on the fresco appeal to your senses. On looking up, you travel into a dreamland. Not surprising, as it’s Yslaire, the cartoonist-drawer of Sambre and of Bidouille and Violette who once again offers us a strange and pastoral ambience... that’s so poetic.

item.title: "Nero" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: He appeared in 1946 and is published in a Flemish daily. Marc Sleen, his creator, whose publication rate some think might well feature in the record book, has brought out some 200 albums alone.

item.title: "Cori the ship’s boy" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Cori and his colourful worlds were created in 1949 by Bob de Moor, one of the last " masters " of the clear line, a style with which he often came into close contact with Hergé, to whom he was the first assistant until his death.

item.title: "Nick’s dream" Comic Strip Wall
item.body:
Standing before this fresco, you’ll be enticed to dream, either for a moment before continuing on your way or by entering into the world of Nic, created by Hermann, uncannily talented in the realist style with, among others, the Jeremiah, Comanche and Bernard Prince series.
 
 

Afficher Bruxelles et la Bande Dessinée / Brussels Comic Strip trail sur une carte plus grande

item.title: "Caroline Baldwin" Comic Strip Wall
item.body:
This lovely adventuress, entrusted with solving the most difficult mysteries, embellishes the windows of the canal district. She is the protégée heroine of André Taymans, a young cartoonist influenced by the clear line of Franquin and Greg.
 

Afficher Bruxelles et la Bande Dessinée / Brussels Comic Strip trail sur une carte plus grande

item.title: "Lucky Luke" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: One of the biggest frescos on the trail (180m2) for one of the biggest classics of Belgian comic strip, in which the cowboy who shoots faster than his shadow, lays down the law and tackles the Daltons. Morris, who was one of the group of four (Franquin, Jijé, Will), was awarded for the whole of his career by “le prix spécial” from the highly-renowned comic strip festival of Angoulème.

item.title: "Astérix & Obelix" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: 50 metres farther along, one of the biggest fresco painted in Brussels is none other than that of Asterix and his companions intent on their favourite hobby: charging at the Romans. It’s a well-known fact that, of all the Gauls, the Belgians are the bravest! This great classic by Goscinny and Uderzo has been translated into 110 languages and sold more than 300 million albums. Don’t hesitate to push open the gate to admire the fresco close up.

item.title: "Isabelle" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Isabelle, the little girl with red hair, Calendula, the witch and Ursule, the nice aunt, make up this poetic wall, which provides a flash of light in the middle of this working-class district. Will is their creator and is also the man to whom we owe the “Tif et Tondu” series.

item.title: "Ric Hochet" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: He’s one of those hyperactive characters of comic strip. A journalist and very athletic, he pursues his investigations at the wheel of his Porsche. Tibet, who draws him, keeps his readers enthralled right up to the last illustration plate, thanks to a versatile and slightly Disney-caricatured style, which has since won quite a following.

item.title: "Victor Sackville" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: A spy in the service of His Majesty during the First World War, Sackville, an elegant figure created by Francis Carin, moves around all the hotspots of Europe in those days and discovers the attractions of Brussels while fulfilling his secret missions.

item.title: "Broussaille" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Hand-in-hand is how Broussaille and his girlfriend decided to walk through the streets of Brussels. Broussaille appears for the first time in the Spirou magazine where he sweeps his readers along from one discovery and adventure to the next. Frank Pé, a real nature lover, is responsible for drawing this warm series and a series called Zoo.

item.title: "Olivier Rameau" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Flower power! Olivier Rameau holds out his hand to the sensual Colombe Tiredaile. In their utopian world, you pay not with money but with tears of joy, songs, laughter or a big kiss. Cartoonist Dany and writer Greg produced this poetic fantasy series in the crazy days of 1968.

item.title: "Le jeune Albert" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Le jeune Albert, a naughty, roguish figure of Brussels, was created in 1982 by Yves Chaland, an other French exception on this comic strip trail. Waiting here for a yellow period tram, like the trams that can still be seen during the weekend on some Brussels’ lines.

item.title: "Blondin & Cirage" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Jijé, a real bastion of Belgian comic strip, in the same way as Hergé, created the Blondin et Cirage series in 1939, adding to the hundred other works he’d created, including Jerry Spring and Spirou and Fantasio.

item.title: "Odilon Verjus" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: The famous potbellied missionary and his clumsy young assistant, entrusted with the task of fulfilling the Vatican’s most thankless missions, have found an address to their liking, 13 rue des Capucins. It is therefore highly possible that the fresco of Verron and Yann will soon become a place of pilgrimage in its own right !

item.title: "Jojo" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Jojo, the first cartoon by the cartoonist André Geerts, made its appearance by chance in the Spirou magazine in 1983 when the magazine editor asked its author to fill an empty quarter of a page. This resulted in a figure who lives in the working-class districts and who has, since then, continued to please young and old alike.

item.title: "The Beaver Patrol" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: It is to Mitacq that we owe this gripping series based on the adventures of a patrol of young scouts continuously embroiled in the craziest adventures. Mitacq is also one of the bastions of Belgian comic strip and is considered one of the greatest contributors to the famous Spirou newspaper.

item.title: "Le Chat" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: The self-mockery of Geluck, symbol of Belgium who doesn’t take himself too seriously, hits the bulls-eye once again by putting the Chat in the role of the Skieven Architect, a typical insult of the Marolles population since Poelaert built the imposing Palais de Justice, which overlooks this working-class district of Brussels.

item.title: "Quick & Flupke" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: The two Ketjes of Brussels created by the cartoonist of one of the most famous comic strip series in the world. Hergé, the father of Tintin, loved to bring this typical working-class quarter (les Marolles) alive again on his illustration plates. This is where the two scamps were always ready to play a nasty trick on passers-by. So stay on your toes - Hergé gathered a lot of material to illustrate each of his albums. A Quick or Flupke can’t be far away.

item.title: "Passe moi l’ciel" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: The fresco of Stuff and Janry is taken from a series published in the Spirou magazine in the nineties. Janry also wrote and drew le Petit Spirou, star of another comic strip fresco on view in Bruparck, near the Atomium.

item.title: "Titeuf" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Suzy has an egghead, Tintin a quiff. Titeuf has both. Deriving his name from the egghead, "petit oeuf" was corrupted into Titeuf. But it is thanks to his proud, rebellious straw yellow crest that everyone immediately recognises him wherever he goes. It is not unlikely his behaviour has something to do with that as well. Look at the comic strip mural. Is Titeuf on a school trip to the globes of the Atomium in Brussels and checking in the convex mirror to see if his hair is alright? Or was it an attempt to spy on the girls from the air? With a cheeky show-off, you never know.

item.title: "Tintin" Comic Strip Wall (Midi Station)
item.body: At the exit of the main Gare du Midi station concourse (Place Horta side), Tintin is displayed over a 64m2 surface to the delight of passengers passing through this transit area. This artwork is taken from the "Tintin in America" album.

item.title: "Debbie" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Is it not heroic to take the dog for a walk so happily and carefree through the city? The dog is named Timmy; the girl is called Debbie. Well actually, in Bruges she is called Tiny. In Tournai people know her as Martine, in Tirana as Zana, in Madrid as Martita, in Cagliari as Cristina, in Skopje as Mapuka, in Ankara as Aysegül, in Maribor as Marinka and in Malmö as Mimmi.

item.title: "Le Roi des Mouches" Comic Strip Wall (Mezzo)
item.body: Look at the names above the intact cages: King Kong and the Minotaur will remain locked up in the imaginary zoo in the shadow of the Atomium for some time yet. The enthusiastic boy who loves Batman and flared trousers chose to free the Yeti. The animal looks more like a hairy, oversized gorilla but it is the Yeti.

item.title: "Lincoln" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: As you can see on the mural in rue des Palais, things are pretty rough in their comic. Lincoln is the young man with the hat who is ready to box with the giant who is rolling up his sleeves. It is not the first time this grouchy, lonesome cowboy lets his fists do the talking or gets into a fight. Lincoln is a born brawler and a notorious grumbler who is bone-idle. But God is relying on this specimen of the human species to restore some order, superhero-style, at the start of the twentieth century.
item.address: Rue des palais outre-pont/Paleizenstraat over de Bruggen

item.title: "Petit Spirou" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Between 1981 and 1998, Spirou was handled by Tome and Janry. The pair got to know each other when they were just known as Richard Vandevelde and Jean-Philippe Geurts. In 1983, they brought out a special issue with a gag about Spirou's childhood. Little Spirou was born. He is definitely not an incorruptible hero of unimpeachable character, but more of a cheeky rascal with a rather premature, naive interest in sex and an unbridled imagination. Characteristics that do not do him any favours when he is repeatedly the victim of incomprehensible and sometimes weird teachers.
item.address: Boulevard du Centenaire (Place de Bruparck)/Eeuwfeestlaan (Bruparck plein)

item.title: "Gaston" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: He thinks it's another day that is just far too beautiful to give to the boss, and so he is leaning on the window sill, playing with his yo-yo. The fact that the yo-yo is bound to hit a random passer-by on the head was written in the stars. You are either Gaston Lagaffe or you're not.

item.title: "Monsieur Jean" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: One of the exceptions on the comic strip trail, “Monsieur Jean” by Berberian and Dupuy, and equally so “le jeune Albert” (whom you’ll discover farther on), are the inventions of French rather than Belgian authors Their authors were recognised by the prestigious Alph’art prize from the Comic Strip Festival of Angoulème.

item.title: "FC de Kampioenen" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: FC De Kampioenen is not a real club, but the name of a hugely popular television series that ran from 1990 to 2011. Since 1997, FC De Kampioenen have also existed in comic strip form. The comic books are drawn by Hec Leemans. On the mural, you will recognise the main characters.

item.title: "La Vache" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Look at the two exuberant murals adorning the Sleepwell youth hostel. You do not know what to look at first. The Magritte bowler hats? The Yellow Mark on the sphere of the Atomium? The cow on the skateboard is called Kobe. She is Secret Agent Pi = 3.1416, and was the muse for De Moor and writer Stephen Desberg for a series of exuberant, mischievous, slightly anarchic comics. On the second fresco, Kobe is wondering where that enthusiastic mouse inside Tintin's rocket is travelling to. ‘When I read your books it's like a pot of paint being thrown in my face", an artist friend once told Johan De Moor.
item.address: Dans l'hôtel "Sleepwell" - Rue du Damier 23/In het "Sleepwel" hôtel - Damstraat 23

item.title: "Yoko Tsuno" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Together with air hostess Natasja, Yoko Tsuno was one of the first comic strip women to get her own series in the early '70s. She represents a break with the stereotypical image of women. She is an electrical engineer, a keen space traveller and just as bold, courageous and adventurous as her male colleague comic strip heroes.

item.title: "XIII" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: For many action heroes, the key question is: what villain should I defeat before he destroys the world? For XIII the question of questions is: Who am I? Like Jason Bourne in the film, XIII is a trained fighting machine whose main characteristic is a failing memory. While searching for his true identity and wondering why so many people seem to be trying to kill him, he stumbles from one adventure into the next.
item.address: Rue Philippe de Champagne/Philippe de Champagnestraat

item.title: "Corto Maltese" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Together, the four drawings on Quai des Péniches are eighty metres long. They’re taken from the albums Les Ethiopiques (Corto Maltese in Africa), Corto Maltese in Siberia, The Golden House of Samarkand and The Celts.

item.title: "Natacha" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Natacha, the air hostess, is much more than just a pretty blond. This is a determined young woman with a highly developed sense of justice.

item.title: "Gil Jordan" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: Gil Jourdan is the detective driving the yellow car. In the passenger seat is Libellule, the ex-burglar who, with varying degrees of success, assists the sometimes rather haughty detective.

item.title: "De Kiekeboes" Comic Strip Wall
item.body: You’d have to go a long way to find a Fleming who doesn’t know that the man with the moustache sitting behind the camera is called Marcel Kiekeboe !

item.title: Hergé Comic Strip Wall (Luxemburg Sation)
item.body: Inaugurated in 2009, a massive Hergé mural greets visitors at the main entrance of the Bruxelles-Luxembourg Station. Its image was first published in Le Soir newspaper on 27 October 1932, and notably features Quick and Flupke, as well as the detectives Thomson and Thompson.
item.address: Entrée de la Gare du Luxembourg - Rue de Trèves/Luxemburg station - Trierstraat

item.title: "Marsupilami" Comic Strip Wall
item.body:
On 8th May 2013 a new fresco was inaugurated on the Avenue Houba de Strooper.
 
The Marsupilami, famous friend of Spirou since 1952, recently joined the Comic strip walk of Brussels. The chosen location is the Avenue Houba de Strooper. Why? The legend tells that Franquin found his inspiration for the Marsupilami’s “Houba, Houba” scream when he walked on this avenue.
 
The realization was given to Farmprod, a group of Belgian and French artists based in Brussels since 20003.
 
Copyright picture: Guy Detienne- www.bd-en-ville.be
item.address: Avenue Houba de Strooper/Houba de Strooperlaan

item.title: Thorgal Comic Strip Wall
item.body:
To the delight of both local residents and passers-by Thorgal and his wife Aaricia now watch over Place Anneessens.
 
Thorgal, famous Viking hero and brainchild of Jean Van Hamme and Grzegorz Rosinski, is the latest addition to Brussels’ comic strip trail. It is in fact the 49th cartoon mural of the route initiated in 1996 and dotted throughout Brussels-Capital Region.
 
The cartoon mural depicts Thorgal with his wife Aaricia and overlooks Place Anneessens at the corner of the square and rue de la Caserne. Hidden behind his shell of mighty warrior Thorgal is committed to justice and freedom and very much aspires to a peaceful life with his beloved wife. Born in 1977 from the encounter between Jean Van Hamme and Grzegorz Rosinski, he features in the first comic book resulting from the collaboration between a graphic artist from the “Eastern Bloc” and a writer from the “Free World” within the context of the Cold War. He also shows if need be that art is able to transcend apparently insurmountable barriers.
 
The project was entrusted to Urbana Project, a collective of Brussels artists led by Nicolas Moreel.

item.title: Le Lombard
item.body: Close to the Midi Railway Station sits the "Tintin Building", a listed historical monument that was to become home to the Éditions du Lombard publishing house. The publisher’s went on to put out Tintin/Kuifje magazine from 1946 to 1988. The company’s ensign consisting of the image of Tintin and Snowy is one of the landmark emblems of Brussels.

item.title: Manneken-Pis
item.body: This bronze statuette, created in the 17th century by J. Duquesnoy the elder, embodies the irreverent spirit of Brussels. Also known as "Little Julian", due to confusion with another fountain, het Juliaensborreke, it was one of the many fountains serving the city. From being a public fountain, the little fellow has now become a legendary figure. He has been given numerous costumes and decorations and his wardrobe now comprises some 800 items, recently restyled in an appealing scenography (see Museum of the City of Brussels). The oldest (known) costume was given to him by the Elector of Bavaria in 1698. Manneken-Pis has, alas, been the victim of several acts of vandalism. It was in 1745 that he was kidnapped for the first time by the English. Two years later, it was the turn of the French to steal him. Hearing of this, Louis XV gave him, by way of reparation for this outrage, a rich costume in gold brocade and decorated him with the cross of Saint-Louis. In 1817, the statuette was stolen again, this time by a reprieved French convict, and was found broken in pieces. The fragments were used to make the statuette which you can see today on the old fountain.

item.title: " Stam & Pilou " Comic Strip Wall
item.body: The little acrobat is called Stam. Girl-next-door Pilou is sitting on his head. The rascals star play the leading roles in light-hearted stories with lots of practical jokes and situational humour. The sign that Grandpa Fons is holding says "Sprekt a mooiertoêl!", which is Brussels dialect for "speak your mother tongue".
item.address: La Fleur en Papier Doré, Rue des Alexiens 53-55/Het Goudblommeke in Papier, Cellebroersstraat 53-55

item.title: The Magritte Fountain (Place de Ninove)
item.body: On the pleasant place de Ninove you will come across rather a strange fountain. If you stand back and look at it from a distance you will discover its secret. Placed on a base in blue stone, the basin is cut in the shape of Magritte's profile and topped by a jet of water which, when falling into the basin, forms the profile of the surrealist painter. This fountain is the work of the Italian artist Luca Maria Patella in cooperation with the Comité des Arts Urbains.

item.title: The Pol Bury Fountain
item.body: The magnificent fountain that adorns the entrance to the prolongation to the Boulevard Emile Jacqmain is the work of the Belgian surrealist artist Pol Bury. It is comprised of 21 steel cylinders, 2 to 3 m in height, topped by a precariously balanced sphere that oscillates to the movements of the water pouring from the fountain. Two other works by Pol Bury can be admired around Brussels: one on rue de Ligne and the other on the ceiling of the Bourse underground station.

item.title: Place de Dinant
item.body: If you look carefully, you will notice, here and there, the thoughts of a few surrealists decorating the urban furniture of this small square. The most remarkable is without a doubt that taken from the "Guestbook of the Fleur en Papier Doré" by Geert (Gérard) Van Bruaene, "Being alive is an excellent reason to live". Geert Van Bruaene is the founder of the Fleur en Papier Doré, a small bar situated just opposite the square, where Magritte and his surrealist friends met every week.

item.title: Schaerbeek cemetery
item.body: Although more discreet than Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris, Schaerbeek cemetery can also be considered as an essential stop on any tour by visitors to our capital. If offers a peaceful setting for a walk to discover several iconic personalities that have left their mark on Brussels. Several have a connection to Surrealism, such as Magritte and his wife or the poet Marcel Mariën, who sends us this message from beyond the grave "Il n'y a aucun mérite à être quoi que ce soit" (There is no merit in being anything). Schaerbeek Cemetery is also the resting place of many other illustrious personalities such as the resistant Andrée De Jongh, the explorer Ernest Cambier or again the statesman and writer Louis Bertrand.

item.title: Magritte & Delvaux frescoes in the Square
item.body: A majestic glass cube at the very heart of Brussels hides 3 little marvels. Vast mural paintings by the great Belgian masters: Magritte, Delvaux (41 m long and 4 m high) and Van Lint. They have been lovingly restored and integrated into the new design of the Square. The Square is a conference centre, only open to professionals. Individuals can only discover these frescos on request.

item.title: Hôtel Ravenstein
item.body: Geert (Gérard) Van Bruaene, an anti-conformist poet, gallerist and friend of the Surrealist group, opened his first gallery "Le Cabinet Maldoror" (1921) in the Hôtel Ravenstein. His extraordinary flair meant that he was one of the first to exhibit artists such as Paul Klee, Max Ernst and René Magritte. The Cabinet Maldoror quickly became the place to go for art in Brussels. And yet, Geert Van Bruaene was in no sense a business man and the "Cabinet de Maldoror" had to close its doors, only to open again under the name of "A la Vierge Poupine" (1924) on the rue de Namur, where he continued to be a pioneering exhibitor of Surrealist works.

item.title: The Academy of Fine Arts of Belgium
item.body: Created in 1711, the Academy of Fine Arts of Belgium can look back proudly over 300 years of history. Illustrious artists have taken their first steps and put on their first exhibitions there. The Academy, only naturally, played a role in the development of the Surrealist movement as its past students include René Magritte (1916-1918) and Paul Delvaux, who first studied architecture (1916-1917) before switching to painting (1920-1924). The surrealist works were yet to come but the young artists tried their hand at other techniques such as impressionism and expressionism.

item.title: Smurf Statue
item.body:
When the idea of creating a Smurf statue was presented to Studio Peyo, they first did some research to find the appropriate pose and attitude. Numerous sketches were made and given the impressive size of the statue the scale of the Smurf needed to be expressed so he was placed on a mushroom. He also needed to look his usual warm and friendly self so was given a broad smurfy smile, thus inviting people to come into the gallery or to come and pose next to him.

Design: Studio Peyo
Sculptor: Maryline Garbe
Statue height: 3,80 m
Base height: 1 m
Total height: 4,80 m
Statue weight: 1 ton
Base weight: 9 tons
Total weight: 10 tons
Number of man hours: 700 hours (= 6 weeks)
Production team: 6 people
Location: Grasmarkt, 1000 Brussels - next to the Horta Gallery (in Brussels Central Station)

item.title: 13 maisons
